awd_titl_txt: RCN UBE: MIRC and MB Research Coordination - Food, Energy, Water, Ecosystem Resources (FEWER)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Mississippi River and the Mekong River are among the largest river systems in the world.  Both provide food, energy, water, and ecosystem resources to millions of people.  The history of anthropogenic perturbations (e.g., dam building) and challenges due to climate change continue to impact these river systems and the ecosystems that they support.  The purpose of the Food, Energy, Water, and Ecosystem Resources (FEWER) Research Coordination Network (RCN) project is to facilitate the networking of scientists within the Minority Institute Research Collaborative (MIRC) - which consists of faculty-scientists from more than 20 U.S. institutions and between MIRC-affiliated scientists and faculty from institutions in Vietnam, Thailand, Malaysia, and Cambodia - to address scientific problems of mutual interest.  The FEWER RCN will focus on four areas in biology: (1) Aquatic Biology and Ecosystem Science; (2) Traditional-Use Plants and Natural Products; (3) Biofuel Feedstocks and Enzyme Systems; and (4) Impact of Climate Change on Biodiversity in the Mekong Basin.  Specific research projects will be developed under one of these themes and research groups consisting of faculty and students from more than one institution within the network will submit position papers to the FEWER RCN steering committee so that the initiation of projects may be scheduled during the term of the grant.  Faculty are expected to engage graduate students and undergraduates in this research using a variety of mechanisms, including institutional funding for undergraduates, REU funding that is available across the network, and other funding sources.  A few student internship awards will be available directly through the RCN. 
 
The FEWER RCN will enhance emerging areas in food, energy, water and ecosystem resources and facilitate new research collaborations between scientists within MIRC and between MIRC and the international partners.  From an academic development perspective, this project aims to increase the number of minority and minority-serving faculty engaged in international research. It will also address scientific problems of importance to stakeholders within the Mississippi River system and the Lower Mekong Basin.  This project is aligned with the goals of the U.S. Department of State's "Lower Mekong Initiative" and officials from governments within foreign partner countries as well as the U.S. State Department are aware of and will be informed on a periodic basis of results from this NSF-funded RCN effort. This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange/finalreport/).

por.por_cntn:
This NSF Research Coordination Network (RCN) project focused on developing a network of research scientists between universities in the U.S. (including the University of Arkansas) and those in the southeast Asian countries including Vietnam and Thailand.  The RCN project provided travel funds and some research supplies for conducting workshops and environmental sampling training in support of collaborative science and student training activities. In addition to providing participant support (e.g., travel) for graduate students and a few undergraduates, a separate NSF REU award (Award No. 1659858) was leveraged to support additional undergraduate student participation in RCN events in southeast Asia and the U.S.  In terms of intellectual merit, this RCN project followed the principal scientist's participation in a US-Vietnam Joint Committee Meeting on Science and Technology spear-headed by the U.S. Department of State with participation of the NSF.  In contribution to the efforts of building science and technology collaboration between the two nations, this RCN grant led to a year-long research exchange for one Vietnamese student from Can Tho University and a graduate from Vietnam National University completing a master's degree at the University of Arkansas. Another Malaysian student is completing a graduate degree at the University of Maine. The principal scientist also served on the PhD committee of a student from King Mongkut's University of Technology Thonburi. She is not a post-doctoral scholar in the PIs lab. An MOU was also signed between Amity University (India) and the University of Arkansas as part of an expansion of this network and a PhD student from Amity Institute of Virology is conducting research in the PIs lab at the University of Arkansas. In terms of broader scientific impact, several peer-reviewed papers have been published or are in preparation that include co-authors from participating institutions. Multiple conference presentations were delivered in the U.S. and abroad. In terms of broadening participation, U.S. students from historically underrepresented racial/ethnic and economic groups engaged in international research opportunities that they otherwise would not likely have been able to access. Overall, this project contributes to the broader goal with the U.S. government to establish ties and build collaborative opportunities with insititutions in southeast Asia.
